Begin CPR immediately and call EMS after 5 minutes
Tap the child, yell for help, and assess breathing and pulse within 10 seconds
Deliver two rescue breaths and then check for pulse

questions.text: A 15-year-old adolescent collapses while playing basketball at school. He is found to be unresponsive and not breathing. What is the most appropriate next step in management
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Emergency Response Steps When Alone:

  • Tap their shoulder and talk loudly to the child to determine if they are responsive.
  • If the child does not respond and is not breathing (or is only gasping for breath), yell for help.
    If someone responds, send the second person to call 911 and to get an AED.
  • Assess if they are breathing while feeling for the child's carotid pulse (on the side of the neck) or femoral pulse (on the inner thigh in the crease between their leg and groin) for no more than 10 seconds.
  • If you cannot feel a pulse (or if you are unsure), begin CPR by doing 30 compressions followed by two breaths. If you can feel a pulse but the pulse rate is less than 60 beats per minute, you should begin CPR. This rate is too slow for a child.
  • After doing CPR for about two minutes (usually about five cycles of 30 compressions and two breaths), and if help has not arrived, call EMS while staying with the child. The ILCOR emphasises that cell phones are available everywhere now, and most have a built-in speakerphone. Get an AED if you know where one is.
  • Use and follow AED prompts when available while continuing CPR until EMS arrives or until the child's condition normalises.

questions.text: A child develops sudden cardiac arrest, and CPR is initiated. Rhythm check reveals asystole, and administration of epinephrine is planned. However, intravenous access cannot be secured immediately. What is the most appropriate alternative route for administering epinephrine in this situation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In pediatric cardiac arrest, if the central or peripheral venous access is not immediately achieved, intraosseous access should be secured.

  • The usual site for intraosseous access isthe upper end of the tibia, medial to the tibial tuberosity.
  • Other sites include the distal femur, the lower end of the tibia above the medial malleolus and the anterior superior iliac spine.
  • All drugs and infusions which can be given via the intravenous route can also be administered via the intraosseous route.

Explanation of other options:

Intracardiac (Option A): Intracardiac route is no longer recommended due to the high risk of myocardial injury and cardiac tamponade.

Intramuscular (Option B): The Intramuscular route has slow and unreliable absorption, making it unsuitable in emergency situations like cardiac arrest. IM epinephrine is specifically indicated for anaphylaxis, not for cardiac arrest management.

Tracheal (Option D): The tracheal route is not a preferred site even in emergencies. However, if even intraosseous access is not possible, it can be considered for lipid-soluble agents like epinephrine, lidocaine, atropine and naloxone, if indicated.

questions.text: What is the recommended chest compression rate during CPR in a child according to PALS 2020 guidelines?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

As per CPR guidelines for children in PALS 2020,

Upon recognition of cardiac arrest, rescuers should begin CPR with both chest compressions and rescue breaths. The components of high-quality pediatric CPR include:

  • Optimal hand positioning
  • Appropriate chest compression rate:
    • Chest compressions should be provided at a rate of 100-­ 120 compressions per minute.
  • Adequate chest compression depth:
    • The goal chest compression depth for infants and children is at least one-­ third the anterior-­ posterior diameter of the chest, which is approximately 4 cm in infants and 5 cm in children.
    • For children who have reached puberty, the adult depth of 5-­ 6 cm can be used.
  • Minimisation of the duration and frequency of chest compression interruptions during CPR.
  • Allow the chest to fully recoil after each compression to facilitate venous return to the heart.
  • Change the compressor every 2 minutes, or sooner if fatigued
  • Appropriate ventilation rate:
    • If no advanced airway, 15:2 compression-ventilation ratio
    • If an advanced airway, provide continuous compressions and give a breath every 2–3 seconds
  • For single rescuers treating children in cardiac arrest, CPR should begin immediately with cycles of 30 compressions followed by two rescuer breaths for at least 2 minutes.
  • When 2 rescuers are present, cycles of 15 compressions followed by two ventilations should be provided.

questions.text: A 25-day-old infant is brought to the ER. On triage, heart rate is 190 bpm, and blood pressure is 58/39 mmHg. The infant has mottled skin, capillary refill of 5 seconds, and weak peripheral pulses. There was abdominal distension, and the liver edge was palpable below the costal margin. A 20 mL/kg normal saline bolus is given, following which the infant developed pulmonary rales and showed decreased responsiveness. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A neonate presenting with hypotension, poor perfusion, weak pulses, and hepatomegaly is a sign of decompensated shock.
  • After an initial 20 mL/kg NS bolus, pulmonary rales and reduced responsiveness develop, suggesting fluid overload and possible heart failure.
  • The next step in management is to improve systemic perfusionthrough improved cardiac output. This may be achieved with catecholamines.
  • In neonatal shock, IV Dopamine infusion is always the first agent to be started if it is a fluid-refractory shock. IV Epinephrine is considered only if Dopamine resistant.
  • In older children, IV Epinephrine infusion is preferred in cold shock and IV Norepinephrine infusion in warm shock.
  • In this patient, the clinical condition deteriorated after the fluid bolus, indicating fluid overload. Therefore, additional fluid boluses are not appropriate. (Options A, B ruled out)

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant suddenly starts choking while being fed small pieces of soft food. The baby is conscious but unable to cry or cough effectively, and his lips and face have turned blue. While waiting for emergency services to arrive, what is the most appropriate immediate action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation and history strongly suggest choking, causing airway obstruction and resulting in severe hypoxia. In a conscious infant, back blows will help relieve the airway obstruction.

  • Airway obstruction is treated with a sequential approach starting with the head-­ tilt/chin-­ lift manoeuvre to open and support the airway, followed by inspection for a foreign body, and finger-­ sweep clearance or suctioning if one is visualised.
  • Blind suctioning or finger sweeps of the mouth are not recommended. (Option B ruled out)
  • A conscious child suspected of having a partial foreign body obstruction should be permitted to cough spontaneously until coughing is no longer effective, respiratory distress and stridor increase, or the child becomes unconscious.
  • For conscious infants, providers should administer five back blows and then five chest thrusts. After each cycle of back blows and chest thrusts, the child’s mouth should be visually inspected for the presence of the foreign body.
  • For conscious children older than 1 year, providers should give a series of five abdominal thrusts (Heimlich manoeuvre) with the child standing or sitting. (Option C ruled out)
  • After the abdominal thrusts, the airway is examined for a foreign body, which should be removed if visualised.
  • For both infants and children, the sequence is repeated until the object is expelled or the patient loses consciousness, at which time CPR with ventilations should be initiated. (Option A ruled out)
  • If the child becomes unconscious, the child should be gently placed on the ground in a supine position, and ventilation should be initiated; compressions should also be started if the child is pulseless.

Fig. A) Back blows (top) and chest thrusts (bottom) to relieve foreign body airway obstruction. B) Abdominal thrusts with the conscious victim

questions.text: What is the first-line drug recommended for fluid-refractory cold shock in children according to current PALS guidelines?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In case of children with fluid-refractory cold shock, the initial drug to be given is Epinephrine (0.05- 0.3 microgram).

  • Cold shock is most common and presents with cold peripheries and poor pulse, while warm shock presents with warm peripheries and bounding pulses.
  • Both types feature tachycardia, poor perfusion and decreased urine output.

Management of shock in infants and children:

questions.text:
A 4-year-old child is brought to the ED after sustaining burns in a closed space. On examination, the child is drowsy and tachypneic. Arterial blood gas revealed the following:
PaO2 78 mmHg; PaCO2 32 mmHg
Serum bicarbonate 16 mmol/L; Serum lactate 6.
Which of the following is the factor most associated with mortality in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Inhalation injury is the most important factor associated with increased mortality in pediatric burns. This occurs when the child inhales smoke, hot gases, or toxic fumes, often in closed-space fires. In this case, the child is likely experiencing severe hypoxia and metabolic acidosis.

  • Inhalation injury should be suspected based on a history of sustained exposure to smoke in association with the burn injury, such as being confined in a closed space or from an indoor explosion.
  • Usually presents with decreased level of consciousness or with evidence of carbon deposits in the oropharynx or nose, singed facial hair, or carbonaceous sputum.
  • While inhalation injury is the most important factor resulting in early mortality, late mortality in pediatric burn patients is most commonly due to sepsis and multi-organ failure.
  • Inhalation injury is of three types:
    • Toxic gases
    • Upper airway oedema
    • Lower airway injury.

Inhalation injury:

  • Acute asphyxia is the most common cause of death at the scene.
  • Carbon monoxide poisoning presents with headache, nausea, drowsiness, confusion, and coma in severe cases.
  • Pulse oximetry is unreliable in CO poisoning, while an ABG with co-oximetry to check carboxyhemoglobin is reliable.
  • Patients should receive 100% oxygen until the HbCO level is <10% and adequate oxygenation is confirmed.
  • Significant CO poisoning (level >25%) may require hyperbaric oxygen therapy.
  • Cyanide poisoning is suspected in persistent metabolic acidosis despite fluid resuscitation, especially with synthetic material burns.

Upper airway oedema:

  • The thermal damage due to burns can lead to oedema of the glottis, trachea, bronchi and bronchioles with decreased ventilation and trapping of secretions and inflammatory exudates.
  • The treatment priority for oedema of the upper airway caused by inhalation injury focuses on establishing and maintaining a patent airway.
  • If airway obstruction is apparent, prompt and early nasotracheal or orotracheal intubation is indicated to maintain airway patency and assure adequate ventilation and oxygenation.

Parenchymal Injury:

  • Pneumonitis peaks after 3-5 days of injury.
  • Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be required in patients who have significant hypoxia, hypercarbia, or mental status changes caused by smoke inhalation.
  • Wheezing and bronchospasm are common, and use of inhaled bronchodilators is often helpful.
  • Missing out or inadequate diagnosis of respiratory burns has a prolonged damaging effect, leading to bronchopneumonia and respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child developed severe hypothermia while trekking in cold weather. An ECG is performed, and the tracing is shown below. What is the most likely abnormality?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ECG shows a positive deflection at the junction of the QRS complex and ST segment. This is known as a J wave, which is a classic finding in hypothermia.

J wave or Osborn wave:

  • Osborn wave or J wave is a positive wave seen at the J-point on the ECG
  • The J point in the ECG is the point where the QRS complex joins the ST segment.
  • Characteristically seen in hypothermia (typically Temp < 30 °C), but they are not pathognomic.
  • Non-hypothermic causes of J wave:
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Acute myocardial ischaemia
    • Severe myocarditis
    • Brugada syndrome
  • Compared to other hypothermia-induced ECG abnormalities (e.g. sinus bradycardia, supraventricular arrhythmias, QT prolongation and AV block), the Osborn wave is thought to be the most specific.

Explanation of other options:

Prolonged PR interval (Option A): The PR interval is the time from the onset of the P wave to the start of the QRS complex. It reflects conduction through the AV node. Delayed conduction through the AV node causes a prolonged PR interval (>200ms), which can lead to 1st degree AV block.

U wave (Option B): The U wave is a small (0.5 mm) deflection immediately following the T wave. Prominent U waves are most commonly found in association with bradycardia and severe hypokalemia.

Tall R wave (Option C): The R wave is the first upward deflection after the P wave. The R wave represents early ventricular depolarisation. Tall R waves are seen post-myocardial infarction, RVH, RBBB and pre-excitation syndromes like Wolff-parkinson-white syndrome.

A 4 mm size cuffed ET tube is ideal in a 4-year-old child
The depth of insertion of the ET tube in a 4-year-old child should be 14 cm
High cuff pressure >25 cm H20 in a cuffed ETT can cause airway necrosis

questions.text: Which of the following statements about pediatric endotracheal intubation is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The use of cuffed ETTs is recommended in most pediatric populations, as it may decrease the need for ETT changes caused by difficulty ventilating and may decrease the risk of aspiration.

  • Cuffed tubes are preferred in all children beyond neonatal age as it is associated with better pressure delivery in patients with poor lung compliance, prevent peritubal leaks and aspirations without a significant increased risk of subglottic stenosis.
  • Cuffed endotracheal tubes also decrease the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia.
  • In neonates, the risk of subglottic injury outweighs the benefit, so uncuffed tubes remain preferred.
  • Cuff pressure should be maintained at <20-25 cm H2O to prevent airway necrosis. (Option D ruled out)

Size of endotracheal tube:

  • An appropriately sized endotracheal tube is used. Beyond 1 year, the size of the uncuffed tube is:
  • Cuffed ETTs should generally be 0.5 mm smaller.

Depth of insertion of the endotracheal tube:

  • The depth of insertion of the tube is approximately three times its inner diameter.
  • In neonates, the endotracheal tube is inserted to a depth of:
  • In children >2-year-old, the depth of insertion of the endotracheal tube is:
  • Once the patient is intubated, proper ETT placement should be assessed by auscultation of breath sounds, observation of symmetrical chest rise, and analysis of exhaled carbon dioxide by a colourimetric device or a capnographic device that quantifies CO2 elimi- nation.
  • Chest radiography should be obtained to confirm the appropriate tube position.

Explanation of other options:

A 4 mm size cuffed ET tube is ideal in a 4-year-old child (Option B): For an uncuffed tube, as per formula, in a 4-year-old child, the ideal size of uncuffed tube is a 5 mm internal diameter tube. And size of the cuffed tube to be taken is always 0.5 mm less than the uncuffed tube. Hence, the cuffed ET tube size to be used here will be 5 mm - 1 mm = 4 mm size Cuffed ET Tube

The depth of insertion of the ET tube in a 4-year-old child should be 14 cm (Option C): The appropriate depth for endotracheal tube insertion in a 4-year-old child is approximately 14 cm, based on the formula: Depth (cm) = (Age in years / 2) + 12.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child is on a nasal cannula at a flow rate of 3 L/min while on mechanical ventilation. What is the approximate fraction of inspired oxygen being delivered?
A 3-year-old child is on ventilation with a nasal cannula delivering oxygen at 3 L/min. What shall be the FiO2?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A common formula for an estimation of the FiO2 during use of a nasal cannula in older children and adults follows:

FiO2 (%)= 21% + [(Nasal Cannula Flow rate in L/in) x 3]

Hence, the most appropriate approximate FiO2 for 3 L/min via nasal cannula in a child is 30%.

  • A nasal cannula provides low levels of oxygen supplementationand is easy to administer.
  • Oxygen is humidified in a bubble humidifier and delivered via nasal prongs inserted into the nares.
  • In children, a flow rate <5 L/minis most often used because of increasing nasal irritation with higher flow rates.
  • The typical FiO2 value (expressed as a percentage rather than a fraction of 1) using this formula above is between 23% and 40%, although the FiO2 varies according to the size of the child, the respiratory rate, and the volume of air moved with each breath.
  • In a young child, because typical nasal cannula flow rates are a greater percentage of total minute ventilation, significantly higher FiO2 may be provided.

Approximate Oxygen Delivery According to Device and Flow Rates in Infants and Older Children:

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with pneumonia is on supplemental oxygen. Which of the following ABG findings does not mandate initiation of mechanical ventilation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Serum bicarbonate levels by itself is not an indicator for initiating ventilation.
  • Although there are no absolute criteria for the derangement of gas exchange, the following are often used in the decision-­ making to institute respiratory support:
    • PaO2 <60 mm Hg while breathing >60% oxygen
    • PaCO2 >60 mm Hg
    • pH <7.25
  • Low levels of bicarbonate (<22 mEq/L) indicate metabolic acidosis, and if adequate compensation cannot be achieved, PaCO2 will further rise and pH will worsen, necessitating the need for ventilation.
  • Isolated low HCO3- without acidosis or respiratory failure does not require ventilation.

questions.text: A child is found unresponsive but with some signs of life. A first responder performs the head-tilt, chin-lift manoeuvre to open the airway. In which of the following scenarios is this manoeuvre contraindicated due to potential risk?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The head-tilt, chin-lift manoeuvre is contraindicated in cases of suspected cervical spine injury, as it may exacerbate spinal damage. In such situations, a jaw-thrust manoeuvre is the preferred method to open the airway.

  • Opening the airway by lifting the tongue away from the posterior pharynx is a critical step in airway management during basic life support.
  • This is done to prevent the tongue from occluding the airway in an unresponsive or unconscious patient who is not breathing adequately.
  • This can be achieved either by head-tilt, chin-lift manoeuvre or jaw thrust.

Head-tilt, chin-lift manoeuvre:

  • Head-tilt, chin-lift manoeuvreis done to open the airway in an unresponsive child with signs of life present.
  • One hand is used to tilt the head, extending the neck.
  • The index finger of the rescuer's other hand lifts the mandible outward by lifting the chin.
  • Head-tilt should not be performed if a cervical spine injury is suspected.

Jaw thrust:

  • This method should be used in trauma patients with suspected cervical spinal injury.
  • Two or three fingers are placed under each side of the lower jaw at its angle to lift the jaw upwards and outwards.
  • This method is not recommended for lay rescuers because it is difficult to learn and perform effectively and safely.

questions.text: A child in severe hypovolemic shock not responding to fluids was started on the maximal dose of IV epinephrine (2 mcg/kg/min). BP was normalised, but echocardiography showed low cardiac output. Administration of a vasodilator failed to improve perfusion. What is the next best agent to be considered?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Therapy with Type III PDE Inhibitors like Milrinone is considered in cold shock, when the patient is normotensive with low cardiac output and has high vascular resistance despite use of epinephrine and vasodilators.

  • Milrinone is used as an intravenous inotropic agent, being a potent inodilator with systemic and coronary vasodilation.
  • Dose of Milrinone is 0.3 to 0.7 micrograms/kg/min as IV Infusion.
  • However, these agents have a short half-life and should be discontinued as soon as the patient develops tachyarrhythmia, hypotension or diminished systemic vascular resistance.

Vasoactive agents used in managing shock:

Vasopressors:

  • In patients with cold shock refractory to fluid resuscitation, epinephrine is the first-line inotrope of choice. Dopamine can be considered if epinephrine is not available. However, in patients with warm shock, norepinephrine is preferred over epinephrine.

Inotropes:

  • In patients with impaired cardiac contractility, inotropic agents are started. Epinephrine is the first-line inotropic agent in children.
  • Therapy with type III phosphodiesterase inhibitors is considered in patients who are normotensive with low output and high vascular resistance despite the use of epinephrine and vasodilators.

Vasodilators:

  • Vasodilators like nitropruside and nitroglycerin are useful in children with normotensive shock with high systemic vascular resistance shock despite therapy with IV fluids and inotropes.

Explanation of other options:

IV Norepinephrine (Option B): Norepinephrine is the first-line inotrope for managing patients with warm, if refractory to fluid resuscitation.

IV Vasopressin (Option C): Vasopressin is a potent vasoconstrictor used in managing catecholamine-refractory septic shock (warm shock) with low BP due to vasodilation. In cold shock, it might worsen perfusion by further increasing afterload.

IV Dopamine (Option D): Adding dopamine offers no additional benefit as the child is already on the maximal dose of epinephrine. Moreover, dopamine has dose-dependent effects. At low doses, dopamine improves renal perfusion via D1 receptors; at moderate doses, it increases cardiac contractility via β1 receptors; while at high doses, it causes vasoconstriction via α1 receptors.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents 4 hours after accidental ingestion of kerosene. He is afebrile, alert, with HR 130/min, BP 85/50 mmHg, RR 40/min and SpO2 90% at room air. Physical examination revealed nasal flaring, intercostal retractions, and bilateral wheeze on auscultation. Oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Chest x-ray revealed the following findings. Based on the findings, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Management of kerosene (hydrocarbon) ingestion is mainly supportive. The X-ray shows ground glass opacity, indicating ARDS. In cases where children develop significant respiratory distress with bronchospasm, bronchodilators like albuterol can help alleviate airway obstruction.

  • Hydrocarbon ingestion can manifest in respiratory symptoms or systemic symptoms if gastrointestinal or respiratory absorption occurs.
  • The chief manifestation of hydrocarbon toxicity is aspiration pneumonitis caused by to inactivation of type II pneumocytes and resulting surfactant deficiency.

Clinical and Laboratory Manifestations

  • Respiratory symptoms develop early (within 6 hours) due to aspiration during ingestion or following vomiting.
  • Symptoms vary from mild cough and respiratory distress to ARDS and respiratory failure.
  • The chest radiograph may be normal initially or show infiltrates, pleural effusion, ARDS and pneumatoceles.
  • Fever and leukocytosis are common and do not necessarily imply bacterial superinfection.

Management:

  • Gastric decontamination (administration of syrup of ipecac or nasogastric lavage) should be avoided in cases of hydrocarbon ingestion because of the risk of aspiration.
  • Management is primarily supportive.
  • Supplemental oxygen is indicated to treat hypoxemia and/or to decrease the work of breathing.
  • Patients often develop bronchospasm and should be treated with a selective agent, such as Albuterol, also known as salbutamol.
  • Antibiotics are indicated only if there are signs of secondary infection (fever or progression of infiltrates on chest radiography after 48 hours). (Option B ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

Activated charcoal (Option A): Activated charcoal is a potentially useful method of GI decontamination. It adsorbs almost all toxins, except common electrolytes, iron, mineral acids or bases, alcohols, cyanide, most solvents, most water-insoluble compounds (hydrocarbons), pesticides and lithium. Its use is contraindicated in patients with intestinal obstruction, ileus, peritonitis and corrosive ingestions.

Corticosteroids (Option D): Use of inhaled and especially systemic corticosteroids may be reasonable in hydrocarbon ingestion, considering that severe aspiration triggers a massive inflammatory response, but their actual benefit is rather inconclusive.

choices.text: Continue CPR and reassess after 2 min
Deliver 1 shock and resume CPR immediately for 2 min

questions.text: A 11-year-old boy is brought to the ER after he collapsed during a football match at school. On evaluation, he is unconscious, pulseless and not breathing. CPR was initiated immediately, and the monitor showed VF. As per PALS guidelines, what is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In an unresponsive child who is not breathing, if pulseless and the monitor shows VF, immediate defibrillation is the best next step, as VF is a shockable rhythm.

  • VF and VT are shockable rhythms, and immediate defibrillation is the priority because only a shock can terminate VF.
  • According to PALS, the first shock is 2 J/kg, followed by immediate CPR for 2 minutes, after which the rhythm is reassessed, and epinephrine is given if VF persists after the second shock.

Explanation of other options:

Continue CPR and reassess after 2 min (Option A): In shockable rhythms, CPR is continued after the 1st shock; continuing CPR without giving a shock will delay ROSC.

Administer epinephrine 0.1 mg/kg (Option B): Epinephrine is given in VF only if the rhythm persists even after 2nd shock.

Synchronised cardioversion (Option D): Synchronised cardioversion at 0.5-1 J/kg is indicated for wide-complex tachycardia such as VT with a pulse when there is associated cardiopulmonary compromise.

Pediatric advanced life support cardiac arrest algorithm:

choices.text: Synchronised cardioversion is indicated in pulseless VT
Initial management of SVT includes vagal manoeuvre
Epinephrine is the drug of choice for SVT
Sinus tachycardia requires treatment with anti-arrhythmic agents

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding tachycardia management in children is correct according to PALS guidelines?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

As per PALS guidelines, in hemodynamically stable patients with SVT, vagal manoeuvres are effective.

  • For infants and young children, an ice-filled bag placed on the face is the most effective vagal manoeuvre.
  • Older children can be encouraged to perform the Valsalva manoeuvre, or carotid sinus massage can be attempted.
  • The drug of choice for SVT is IV adenosine (1 mg/Kg) given as a rapid bolus. (Option C ruled out)
  • If no response to adenosine, synchronised cardioversion is performed.

Explanation of other options:

Synchronised cardioversion is indicated in pulseless VT (Option A): Pulseless VT, like ventricular fibrillation, is a shockable rhythm and should be treated with defibrillation, starting at 2 J/kg. Synchronised cardioversion is reserved for unstable wide-complex tachycardia - VT with a pulse.

Sinus tachycardia requires treatment with anti-arrhythmic agents (Option D): Sinus tachycardia is usually a physiologic response to factors such as fever, hypovolemia, pain, or anxiety. Management focuses on correcting the underlying cause, and anti-arrhythmic drugs are not indicated.

Pediatric advanced life support: Tachycardia with a pulse algorithm.
